results.title: DreamWorks Animation Masterclass: Jason Schleifer
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Kim Montgomery and Shelley Matulick
results.brief_description:
At the heart of DreamWorks Animation is the desire to tell great stories and inspire audiences.

In a series of masterclass sessions, the creative team behind the studio that brought us ‘Kung Fu Panda’, ‘Shrek’ and ‘Madagascar’, gave an exclusive look inside the professional animation industry.

Jason Schleifer served as Head of Character Animation on DreamWorks Animation’s most recent feature, ‘Mr. Peabody & Sherman’, and has worked on numerous other key titles for the studio including ‘Megamind’, ‘Madagascar’, ‘Madagascar: Escape 2 Africa’, ‘Over the Hedge’ and ‘Shrek the Third’.

Prior to his career at DreamWorks, Schleifer had extensive involvement at Weta Digital, beginning as a Creature Technical Director and later promoted to an Animation Lead while making the ‘Lord of the Rings’ Trilogy.

results.title: DreamWorks Animation Masterclass: Doug Cooper
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Kim Montgomery and Shelley Matulick
results.brief_description:
At the heart of DreamWorks Animation is the desire to tell great stories and inspire audiences.

In a series of masterclass sessions, the creative team behind the studio that brought us ‘Kung Fu Panda’, ‘Shrek’ and ‘Madagascar’, gave an exclusive look inside the professional animation industry.

Doug Cooper (VFX Supervisor) joined DreamWorks in 1998 as a CG Effects Animator and Technical Director on ‘The Prince of Egypt’ and went on to serve as the Digital Supervisor on ‘Spirit: Stallion of the Cimarron’. Previous credits as VFX supervisor include ‘Bee Movie’ and ‘First Flight’ (an animated short).

results.title: DreamWorks Animation Masterclass: Christophe Lautrette
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Kim Montgomery and Shelley Matulick
results.brief_description:
At the heart of DreamWorks Animation is the desire to tell great stories and inspire audiences.

In a series of masterclass sessions, the creative team behind the studio that brought us ‘Kung Fu Panda’, ‘Shrek’ and ‘Madagascar’, gave an exclusive look inside the professional animation industry.

Christophe Lautrette served the role of a Production Designer for DreamWorks Animation’s pre-historic family comedy, ‘The Croods’. During his tenure at DreamWorks Animation, Lautrette has worked as Art Director on various feature films, including ‘Prince of Egypt’, ‘Spirit: Stallion of the Cimarron’, ‘Kung Fu Panda’ and ‘Bee Movie’. He is also the main contributor to DreamWorks Animation’s first personal art publication ‘Moonshine’.

Lautrette is originally from France and he currently resides in Los Angeles, CA.

results.title: Dreamtime this time dreamtime (A)
results.creator_credit: Aboriginal Arts Board and Air Programs International
results.brief_description: An animated treatment of the Aboriginal legends using children’s illustrations from the book “An Aboriginal children’s history of Australia” is intercut with live footage concerning various Aboriginal issues.

results.title: Dreams of return
results.creator_credit: Julie Shiels, North Richmond Community Health Centre, Timorese Association of Victoria and Michael Buckley
results.brief_description: This CDROM has been funded by the Australian Film Commission and is primarily about the experiences of Timorese refugees living in Australia. The work is a contemporary look at identity, resistance and the dream of return to East Timor. The CDROM is shaped around the performance and cultural work (including dance, drumming and storytelling) developed by members of the East Timorese community who are based at the North Richmond community health centre. The work in this CDROM was developed in conjunction with the Timorese association of Victoria.

results.title: Dreams and silence = Reves et silences
results.creator_credit: Sourat Films, FR3, CBA and Omar Al-Qattan
results.brief_description: It is the autumn of 1990 in Jordan. The Islamic movement has declared a Holy War against the West and the Gulf War is at its height. Haifa Samhouri is a middle-aged Palestinian refugee living in Jordan. In this sensitively produced and directed documentary, Haifa talks of her life as a refugee, her love for her homeland, her arranged and loveless marriage, her sons, and her continuing philosophical battle with her religion, Islam, which on the one hand offers salvation and on the other, oppression, especially towards women. Bitter at times but often displaying an ironic sense of humour we see Haifa as she goes about her daily life, confronting, questioning her husband and male neighbours about the role of women within the Islamic faith but also prepared to sacrifice her son in the war if it means winning the war. Juxtaposed to Haifa’s story, is a discourse by an Islamic spiritual leader on the political and philosophical aspects of Islam against the background of the suffering and destruction of the Arab world and the aftermath of the Gulf War. Winner of several awards including Joris Ivens Award (1st prize) International Documentary Film Festival, Amsterdam 1991 and Honorary prize, Best Documentary, Valencia Film Festival, 1991. In Arabic with English and French subtitles.

results.title: Dreamlives [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Jennifer Crone
results.brief_description: Partners in life and art, Sydney photographers Narelle Autio and Trent Park discuss why they are drawn to one another’s work and what inspires and motivates them when they are behind the lens. Cameras follow the pair as they photograph goat racing in Lightning Ridge and attempt to capture the essence of Sydney city. They talk of work on their first collaboration in 2001 - the Seventh wave - which depicted images of Australian beach life and garnered them the World Press Award. They also speak of the moniker of “The Roo couple,” coined for their surrealistic images of dead animals by the roadside.

results.title: Dreamland: a history of early Canadian movies 1895-1939
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Donald Brittain and Kirwan Cox
results.brief_description: People have become so sated with spectacular inventions and achievements that it is now difficult to imagine the sensation created by the first motion picture films, in which people actually moved about on the screen just as in real life. Little is left of those early days of Canadian cinema. But from the footage available, the filmmakers have pieced together an absorbing account of what went on the screens of the nation in those times, and of the people who influenced the fledgling industry. This is a flashback to the past that all will enjoy.

results.title: Dreamland express
results.brief_description: David Anderson’s waking dream is a poetic animated journey through the rich fantasy life of a child’s unconscious, combining elaborate cut-outs, intricate drawn cell animation and live action. A young boy finds himself in a mysterious express train travelling through a forbodeing and surreal landscape.
